I am currently in the following situation:

variable {R M : Type} [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup M] [Module R M] (B N : Submodule R M)

def submodule_cast (h : B ≤ N) : Submodule R N := sorry

where I have a two terms, B and N, of Submodule R M and a proof that B < N and I would like to obtain the corresponding element of Submodule R N. For context, I want this so I can work with the quotient module N/B so a different way of constructing this quotient would be useful as well.
Sorry, this is my first time asking a question here and I do not know how to make the code look nice.
To view B as a submodule of N, you want the docs#LinearMap.range of docs#Submodule.inclusion
Note that you should not label things as haskell here; unlike discord, zulip has native lean support
for making your code look nice: #backticks tells you that this zulips default is to use lean4 highlighting

Another way of making the quotient module would be the image of N in M / B; then it would be a term (of type Submodule (M\/B) rather than a type). What is best depends on your applications. Personally I try to avoid the ↥ as much as possible and have every object either always being a term or always being a type, but this is not always possible.

Jireh Loreaux said:

Thank you for the quick response! To use LinearMap.range, I will need to access the inclusion map B -> N on the underlying modules correct? Is there a simple way of doing this?

Kevin Buzzard said:

Another way of making the quotient module would be the image of N in M / B; then it would be a term (of type Submodule (M\/B) rather than a type). What is best depends on your applications. Personally I try to avoid the ↥ as much as possible and have every object either always being a term or always being a type, but this is not always possible.

I'm trying to prove that a module is Artinian via a filtration argument so I'm trying to use induction and isArtinian_iff_submodule_quotient

Brian Nugent said:

inclusion map B -> N on the underlying modules correct? Is there a simple way of doing this?

That's what I said, you need the range of docs#Submodule.inclusion.
if (h : B ≤ N), the LinearMap.range (Submodule.inclusion h) : Submodule R N is your desired sub-submodule.
(But I agree with Kevin, if you can avoid doing it this way, please do.)
Brian Nugent has marked this topic as resolved.
You might find something useful in the proof that a module with a composition series is finite length.
